009package imagingbook.common.geometry.fitting.ellipse.algebraic;
010
011import static imagingbook.common.math.Arithmetic.sqr;
012
013import java.util.Arrays;
014
015import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.MatrixUtils;
016import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.RealMatrix;
017import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.RealVector;
018
019import ij.IJ;
020import imagingbook.common.geometry.basic.Pnt2d;
021import imagingbook.common.geometry.basic.PntUtils;
022import imagingbook.common.math.Matrix;
023import imagingbook.common.math.eigen.EigenDecompositionJama;
024
025/**
026 * <p>
027 * Algebraic ellipse fit based on Fitzgibbon's method [1], numerically
028 * improved as suggested by Halir and Flusser [2].
029 * See [3, Sec. 11.2.1] for a detailed description.
030 * </p>
031 * 
032 * <p>
033 * Note: This implementation performs data centering or, alternatively, 
034 * accepts a specific reference point. 
035 * Capable of performing an (exact) 5-point fit!
036 * </p>
037 * 
038 * <p>
039 * [1] A. W. Fitzgibbon, M. Pilu, and R. B. Fisher. Direct least-
040 * squares fitting of ellipses. IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis
041 * and Machine Intelligence 21(5), 476-480 (1999).
042 * <br>
043 * [2] R. Halíř and J. Flusser. Numerically stable direct least squares
044 * fitting of ellipses. In "Proceedings of the 6th International
045 * Conference in Central Europe on Computer Graphics and Visualization
046 * (WSCG’98)", pp. 125-132, Plzeň, CZ (February 1998).
047 * <br>
048 * [3] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; An Algorithmic Introduction</em>, 
049 * 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
050 * </p>
051 * 
052 * @author WB
053 * @version 2021/11/06
054 */
055public class EllipseFitFitzgibbonStable implements EllipseFitAlgebraic {
056        
057        private static final RealMatrix C1 = 
058                        Matrix.makeRealMatrix(3, 3,
059                                        0.0,  0.0, 2, 
060                                        0.0, -1.0, 0.0, 
061                                        2,    0.0, 0.0);
062        
063        private static final RealMatrix C1i = 
064                        Matrix.makeRealMatrix(3, 3,
065                                        0.0,  0.0, 0.5, 
066                                        0.0, -1.0, 0.0, 
067                                        0.5,  0.0, 0.0);
068        
069        private final double[] q;       // = (A,B,C,D,E,F) ellipse parameters
070        
071        public EllipseFitFitzgibbonStable(Pnt2d[] points, Pnt2d xref) {
072                this.q = fit(points, xref);
073        }
074        
075        public EllipseFitFitzgibbonStable(Pnt2d[] points) {
076                this(points, PntUtils.centroid(points));
077        }
078
079        @Override
080        public double[] getParameters() {
081                return this.q;
082        }
083        
084        private double[] fit(Pnt2d[] points, Pnt2d xref) {
085                final int n = points.length;
086                if (n < 5) {
087                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("fitter requires at least 5 sample points instead of " + points.length);
088                }
089
090                // reference point
091                final double xr = xref.getX();
092                final double yr = xref.getY();
093
094                RealMatrix X1 = MatrixUtils.createRealMatrix(n, 3);
095                RealMatrix X2 = MatrixUtils.createRealMatrix(n, 3);
096                
097                for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
098                        final double x = points[i].getX() - xr; // center data set
099                        final double y = points[i].getY() - yr;
100                        double[] f1 = {sqr(x), x*y, sqr(y)};
101                        double[] f2 = {x, y, 1};
102                        X1.setRow(i, f1);
103                        X2.setRow(i, f2);
104                }
105
106                // build reduced scatter matrices:
107                RealMatrix S1 = X1.transpose().multiply(X1);
108                RealMatrix S2 = X1.transpose().multiply(X2);
109                RealMatrix S3 = X2.transpose().multiply(X2);            
110                RealMatrix S3i = MatrixUtils.inverse(S3);
111                
112                RealMatrix T = S3i.scalarMultiply(-1).multiply(S2.transpose());         
113                RealMatrix Z = C1i.multiply(S1.add(S2.multiply(T)));
114                
115                // find the eigenvector of Z which satisfies the ellipse constraint:
116//              EigenDecomposition ed = new EigenDecomposition(Z);
117                EigenDecompositionJama ed = new EigenDecompositionJama(Z);
118                double[] p1 = null;
119                for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
120                        RealVector e = ed.getEigenvector(i);
121                        if (e.dotProduct(C1.operate(e)) > 0) {
122                                p1 = e.toArray();
123                                break;
124                        }
125                }
126                
127                if (p1 == null) {
128                        IJ.log("p1 is null! " + Arrays.toString(points));
129                        return null;
130                }
131                
132                double[] p2 = T.operate(p1);
133                
134                RealMatrix U = getDataOffsetCorrectionMatrix(xr, yr);
135                
136                // assemble q
137                return U.operate(Matrix.join(p1, p2));
138        }
139        
140}
